SEARCH
Package sprouts

Interface Var<T extends @Nullable Object>

Type Parameters:
T - The type of the wrapped item.
All Superinterfaces:
Maybe<T>, Val<T>
public interface Var<T extends @Nullable Object> extends Val<T>
A mutable wrapper for an item which can also be mapped to a weakly referencedViewable to be observed for changes using Actions registered through the Viewable.onChange(Channel, Action) method, where the Channel is used to distinguish between changes from different sources (usually application layers like the view model or the view).
Use Val.view() to access a simple no-op live view of the item of this property and register change listeners on it to react to state changes.

The Channel constant passed to Viewable.onChange(Channel, Action) ensures that the corresponding Action callback is only invoked when the Val.fireChange(Channel) method or the set(Channel, Object) method is invoked with the same Channel. Usually you will use the From constants to distinguish between important application layers using the From.VIEW_MODEL or From.VIEW channels.

Note that set(Object) method defaults to the From.VIEW_MODEL channel, which is intended to be used for state changes as part of your core business logic.

So for example if you have a Var which represents the username of a form, then inside your UI you can register a callback using Viewable.onChange(Channel, Action) using the channel From.VIEW_MODEL which will update the UI accordingly when set(Object) is called inside you view model.
On the other hand, when the UI changes the property through the #set(From.View, object) method, all Viewable.onChange(Channel, Action) with the channel From.VIEW listeners will be notified.
Consider the following example property in your view model: 


      // A username property with a validation action:
      private final Var<String> username = Var.of("");
      private final Viewable<String> usernameView = this.username.view().onChange(From.VIEW v -> validateUser(v) );
And the following SwingTree example UI: 

      UI.textField("")
      .peek( tf -> vm.getUsernameView().onChange(From.VIEW_MODEL t -> tf.setText(t.get()) ) )
      .onKeyRelease( e -> vm.getUsername().set(From.VIEW, ta.getText() ) );
Here your view will automatically update the item of the text property and inside your view model you can freely update the username property, and it will then also automatically update the text field in the UI: 

      // Initially empty username:
      username.set( "" ) // triggers 'fireChange(From.VIEW_MODEL)'

If you no longer need to observe a property, you can use the Observable.unsubscribe(Subscriber) method to remove all Actions (which are also Subscribers) registered through Viewable.onChange(Channel, Action).

Note that the name of this class is short for "variable". This name was deliberately chosen because it is short, concise and yet clearly conveys the same meaning as other names used to model this kind of pattern, like "property", "observable object", "observable value", "observable property", etc. Using the names Var and Val also allows for the distinction between mutable and immutable properties without having to resort to prefixes like "mutable" or "immutable" as part of a type that is supposed to be used everywhere in your code.

Please take a look at the living sprouts documentation where you can browse a large collection of examples demonstrating how to use the API of this class.

See Also:
  • A super type of this class with a read-only API.
  • A weakly referenced, read only live view of mutable properties to be used for registering change listeners.

  • Method Details

    • ofNullable

      static <T> Var<@Nullable T> ofNullable(Class<T> type, @Nullable T item)
      Use this factory method to create a new Var instance whose item may or may not be null.
      Var instances returned by this method will also report true for Val.allowsNull().

      Example: 

      
      Var.ofNullable(String.class, null);
      Note that it is required to supply a Class to ensure that the property can return a valid type when Maybe.type() is called.
      Type Parameters:
      T - The type of the wrapped item.
      Parameters:
      type - The type of the item wrapped by the property. This is not only used to check if the item is of the correct type, but also so that the property knows its type, even if the item is null.
      item - The initial item of the property, which may be null.
      Returns:
      A new Var instance.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the given type is null.

    • ofNull

      static <T> Var<@Nullable T> ofNull(Class<T> type)
      A more concise version of ofNullable(Class, Object) which is equivalent to Var.ofNullable(type, null).
      The Var instances returned by this factory method, are nullable, which means their Val.allowsNull() method will always yield true and they will not throw an IllegalArgumentException when set(Object) is called with a null item.
      Type Parameters:
      T - The type of the wrapped item.
      Parameters:
      type - The type of the item wrapped by the property.
      Returns:
      A new Var instance.

    • of

      static <T> Var<T> of(T item)
      This factory method returns a Var describing the given non-null item similar to Optional.of(Object), but specifically designed to be used for MVVM.
      Var instances returned by this method will report false for Val.allowsNull(), because the item is guaranteed to be non-null.
      Type Parameters:
      T - The type of the item held by the Var!
      Parameters:
      item - The initial item of the property which must not be null.
      Returns:
      A new Var instance wrapping the given item.
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - If the given item is null.

    • of

      static <T, V extends T> Var<T> of(Class<T> type, V item)
      This factory method returns a Var describing the given non-null item similar to Optional.of(Object) and its type which may also be a super type of the supplied item.
      Var instances returned by this method will report false for Val.allowsNull(), because the item is guaranteed to be non-null.
      Type Parameters:
      T - The type of the item held by the Var!
      V - The type of the item which is wrapped by the returned Var!
      Parameters:
      type - The type of the item wrapped by the property, or a super type of it.
      item - The initial item of the property which must not be null.
      Returns:
      A new Var instance wrapping the given item.
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - If the given item is null.

    • set

      default Var<T> set(T newItem)
      This method provides the ability to modify the state of the wrapper from the view model channel (see From.VIEW_MODEL). It might have several effects depending on the implementation.
      Parameters:
      newItem - The new item which ought to replace the old one.
      Returns:
      This very wrapper instance, in order to enable method chaining.

    • set

      Var<T> set(Channel channel, T newItem)
      This method provides the ability to modify the state of the wrapper from a custom channel of your choice, usually one of the channels defined in From. It might have several effects depending on the implementation.
      Parameters:
      channel - The channel from which the item is set.
      newItem - The new item which ought to replace the old one.
      Returns:
      This very wrapper instance, in order to enable method chaining.

    • update

      default Var<T> update(Function<T,@Nullable T> mapper)
      A common use-case is to update the item of a property based on the current item. This is especially useful when your property holds larger value oriented types like records for which you want to update one of its fields through a wither.
      This is possible through this method, and it may look something like this: 
      
      record Point(int x, int y){...}
      var myProperty = Var.of(new Point(1,2));
      myProperty.update( it -> it.withY(42) );
      This takes the current item (if it is not null) and applies the provided mapper function to it. The result will then be used to set the new item. So this is essentially a convenience method for the set(Object) method, which means that the same change listeners will be triggered when the item changes.

      Note that this method will not be called when the item is null, use updateNullable(Function) for that.
      Also note that any exceptions thrown by the mapper will not be caught and will be propagated to the caller.

      Parameters:
      mapper - A function which take the current item and returns an item which will be used to set the new item. It is ignored in case of the property item being null.
      Returns:
      This property instance, to allow for fluent method chaining.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the given mapper is null.

    • update

      default Var<T> update(Channel channel, Function<T,@Nullable T> mapper)
      A common use-case is to update the item of a property based on the current item. This is especially useful when your property holds larger value oriented types like records for which you want to update one of its fields through a wither.
      This is possible through this method, and it may look something like this: 
      
      record Point(int x, int y){...}
      var myProperty = Var.of(new Point(1,2));
      myProperty.update(From.View, it -> it.withY(42) );
      This takes the current item (if it is not null) and applies the given mapper function to it, which will then be used to set the new item on the supplied Channel. So this is essentially just a convenience method which will call the set(Channel, Object) for you, which means that the same change listeners will be triggered if the item changes.

      Note that this method will not be called when the item is null, use updateNullable(Function) for that.
      Also note that any exceptions thrown by the mapper will not be caught and will be propagated to the caller.

      Parameters:
      channel - The Channel for which the associated change listener should be invoked.
      mapper - A function which take the current item and returns an item which will be used to set the new item. It is ignored in case of the property item being null.
      Returns:
      This property instance, to allow for fluent method chaining.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the given mapper is null.

    • updateNullable

      default Var<T> updateNullable(Function<@Nullable T,@Nullable T> mapper)
      A common use-case is to update the item of a property based on the current item, but this time the item can be null. This is especially useful when your property holds larger value oriented types like records for which you want to update one of its fields through a wither.
      This is possible using this method, and it may look something like this: 
      
      record Point(int x, int y){...}
      var myProperty = Var.ofNullable(Point.class, new Point(1,2));
      myProperty.updateNullable( it -> it == null ? it : it.withY(42) );
      This takes the current item, even if it is null, and applies the given mapper function to it, whose result will then be used to set the new item. Note that this is essentially just a convenience method which will call the set(Object) for you, which means that the same change listeners will be triggered if the item changes.

      Note that any exceptions thrown by the mapper will not be caught and will be propagated to the caller.

      Parameters:
      mapper - A function which take the current item or null and returns an item which will be used to set the new item.
      Returns:
      This property instance, to allow for fluent method chaining.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the given mapper is null.

    • updateNullable

      default Var<T> updateNullable(Channel channel, Function<@Nullable T,@Nullable T> mapper)
      A common use-case is to update the item of a property based on the current item, but this time the item can be null. This is especially useful when your property holds larger value oriented types like records for which you want to update one of its fields through a wither.
      This is possible using this method, and it may look something like this: 
      
      record Point(int x, int y){...}
      var myProperty = Var.ofNullable(Point.class, new Point(1,2));
      myProperty.updateNullable(From.View, it -> it == null ? it : it.withY(42) );
      This takes the current item, even if it is null, and applies the given mapper function to it, which will then be used to set the new item on the supplied Channel. Note that this is essentially just a convenience method which will call the set(Channel, Object) for you, which means that the same change listeners will be triggered if the item changes.

      Note that any exceptions thrown by the mapper will not be caught and will be propagated to the caller.

      Parameters:
      channel - The Channel for which the associated change listener should be invoked.
      mapper - A function which take the current item or null and returns an item which will be used to set the new item.
      Returns:
      This property instance, to allow for fluent method chaining.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the given mapper is null.

    • withId

      Var<T> withId(String id)
      Use this method to create a new property with an id. This id is used to identify the property in the UI or as a key in a map, which is useful when converting your view model to a JSON object, or similar formats.
      Specified by:
      withId in interface Val<T extends @Nullable Object>
      Parameters:
      id - The id of the property.
      Returns:
      A new Var instance with the given id.

    • map

      default Var<T> map(Function<T,T> mapper)
      If the item is present, then this applies the provided mapping function to it, and return it wrapped in a new Var instance.
      If the item is not present, then an empty Var instance is returned.

      But note that the resulting property does not constitute a live view of this property and will not be updated when this property changes.
      It is functionally very similar to the Optional.map(Function) method.

      If you want to map to a property which is an automatically updated live view of this property, then use the Val.view(Function) method instead. This is essentially the same as Optional.map(Function) but based on Var as the wrapper instead of Optional.

      Specified by:
      map in interface Maybe<T extends @Nullable Object>
      Specified by:
      map in interface Val<T extends @Nullable Object>
      Parameters:
      mapper - The mapping function to apply to an item, if present.
      Returns:
      A new property either empty (containing null) or containing the result of applying the mapping function to the item of this property.

    • mapTo

      default <U extends @Nullable Object> Var<@Nullable U> mapTo(Class<U> type, Function<@NonNull T,U> mapper)
      If the item is present, applies the provided mapping function to it, and returns it wrapped in a new Var instance.
      If the item is not present, then an empty Var instance is returned.

      But note that the resulting property does not constitute a live view of this property and will not be updated when this property changes.
      It is functionally very similar to the Optional.map(Function) method.

      If you want to map to a property which is an automatically updated live view of this property, then use the Val.viewAs(Class, Function) method instead.

      Specified by:
      mapTo in interface Maybe<T extends @Nullable Object>
      Specified by:
      mapTo in interface Val<T extends @Nullable Object>
      Type Parameters:
      U - The type of the item returned from the mapping function
      Parameters:
      type - The type of the item returned from the mapping function
      mapper - the mapping function to apply to an item, if present
      Returns:
      A new property either empty (containing null) or containing the result of applying the mapping function to the item of this property.

    • zoomTo

      default <B> Var<B> zoomTo(Function<T,B> getter, BiFunction<T,B,T> wither)
      Creates a lens property (Var) that focuses on a specific field on the property item type, using a getter and a wither function to access and update the field. This method is used to zoom into an immutable nested data structure, allowing read and write operations on a specific field via getter and wither functions.

      For example, consider a record Author with fields firstName, lastName, birthDate, and books. Using zoomTo, you can create lenses for each field to access and update them individually. 

      
   var author = new Author("John", "Doe", LocalDate.of(1829, 8, 12), Tuple.of("Book1", "Book2"));
   var authorProperty = Var.of(author);

   // Creating lenses for Author fields
   var firstNameLens = authorProperty.zoomTo(Author::firstName, Author::withFirstName);
   var lastNameLens = authorProperty.zoomTo(Author::lastName, Author::withLastName);
   var birthDateLens = authorProperty.zoomTo(Author::birthDate, Author::withBirthDate);
   var booksLens = authorProperty.zoomTo(Author::books, Author::withBooks);

   // Usage example: Update the first name via the lens
   firstNameLens.set("Jane");
      Type Parameters:
      B - The type of the field that the lens will focus on.
      Parameters:
      getter - Function to get the current value of the focused field from the parent object.
      wither - BiFunction to set or update the value of the focused field and return a new instance of the parent object with the updated field.
      Returns:
      A new Var that acts as a lens focusing on the specified field of the parent object.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the given getter or wither function is null.

    • zoomTo

      default <B> Var<B> zoomTo(Lens<T,B> lens)
      Creates a lens property (Var) that focuses on a specific field of the current property item using a supplied Lens implementation. This method is used to zoom into an immutable nested data structure, allowing read and write operations on a specific field via getter and wither functions.

      For example, consider a record TrainStation with various fields like name, location, and platforms. Using zoomTo, you can supply a Lens implementation to create a lens for a specific field. 

      
   record TrainStation(String name, String location, Tuple<Platform> platforms) {...}
   var lensToPlatforms = Lens.of(TrainStation::platforms, TrainStation::withPlatforms);
   // Create a TrainStation property
   var station = new TrainStation("Grand Central", "New York", Tuple.of(new Platform(1), new Platform(2)));
   var stationProperty = Var.of(station);
   // Create a stateful lens for the platforms field
   var platformsProperty = stationProperty.zoomTo(lensToPlatforms);
      Note that the Lens is a generic interface. So instead of the Lens.of(Function, BiFunction) factory method, you may also create more elaborate lenses through a custom implementation.
      The lens in the above example may also be created like so: 
      
   var lensToPlatforms = new Lens<TrainStation, Tuple<Platform>>() {
     public Tuple<Platform> getter( TrainStation station ) {
         return station.platforms();
     }
     public TrainStation wither( TrainStation station, Tuple<Platform> platforms ) {
         return station.withPlatforms(platforms);
     }
   };
      Type Parameters:
      B - The type of the field that the lens will focus on.
      Parameters:
      lens - The Lens implementation to focus on the specified field of the parent object.
      Returns:
      A new Var that acts as a lens focusing on the specified field of the parent object.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the given lens is null.

    • zoomTo

      default <B extends @NonNull Object> Var<B> zoomTo(B nullObject, Function<T,B> getter, BiFunction<T,B,T> wither)
      Creates a lens property (Var) that focuses on a specific field of the item of this property, allowing a default value for whenever the item of this property is null. The lens property produced by this method will use the getter and wither functions to access and update a specific field in the item of this property. But in case of the item of this property being null, then the nullObject will be used as the non-null fallback value for the lens property produced by this method. This method is useful when you don't want your lens property to store null items, despite the parent object storing null items.

      For example, consider a record Book wrapped by a nullable Var<Book> property, which has a publisher field that we want to focus on and zoom into. Using zoomTo with a null object, you can create a lens for the publisher field even when the parent object is null. So when accessing the value of the lens, you will never have to worry about a NullPointerException. 

      
   // We declare a Book and a Publisher record
   record Book(String title, Publisher publisher) {...}
   record Publisher(String name) {...}

   // A nullable book property and a "null" publisher object
   var bookProperty = Var.ofNull(Book.class);
   Publisher nullPublisher = new Publisher("Unknown");

   // Creating a null safe lens property for the publisher field
   var publisherLens = bookProperty.zoomTo(nullPublisher,Book::publisher,Book::withPublisher);
   assert publisherLens.get() == nullPublisher;

   // Updating the book property with a new publisher
   var book = new Book("Some Title", new Publisher("Publisher1"));
   bookProperty.set(book);
   assert publisherLens.get() == book.publisher();
      Type Parameters:
      B - The type of the field that the lens will focus on, which must not be null.
      Parameters:
      nullObject - The object to use when the focused field or its parent object is null.
      getter - Function to get the current value of the focused field from the parent object.
      wither - BiFunction to set or update the value of the focused field and return a new instance of the parent object with the updated field.
      Returns:
      A new Var that acts as a lens focusing on the specified field of the parent object, using the null object when the parent object is null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the given getter or wither function is null.

    • zoomTo

      default <B extends @NonNull Object> Var<B> zoomTo(B nullObject, Lens<T,B> lens)
      Creates a lens property (Var) from the supplied Lens implementation, which focuses on a specific field of the potentially nullable item of this property, where a default non-null value is provided for cases when the item of this property is null. The lens property produced by this method will use the supplied Lens implementation to access and update a specific field in the item of this property. But in case of the item of this property being null, then the nullObject will be used as the non-null fallback value for the lens property produced by this method. This method is useful when you don't want your lens property to store null items, despite the parent object storing null items.

      For example, consider a record Book wrapped by a nullable Var<Book>, with a publisher field that we want to focus on. Using zoomTo with a null object, you can create a lens for the publisher field even when the parent object is null. So when accessing the value of the lens, you will never have to worry about a NullPointerException. 

      
   // We declare a Book and a Publisher record
   record Book(String title, Publisher publisher) {...}
   record Publisher(String name) {...}

   // A nullable book property and a "null" publisher object
   var bookProperty = Var.ofNull(Book.class);
   Publisher nullPublisher = new Publisher("Unknown");

   // Creating a null safe lens property for the publisher field
   var publisherLens = bookProperty.zoomTo(nullPublisher, Lens.of(Book::publisher,Book::withPublisher));
   assert publisherLens.get() == nullPublisher;

   // Updating the book property with a new publisher
   var book = new Book("Some Title", new Publisher("Publisher1"));
   bookProperty.set(book);
   assert publisherLens.get() == book.publisher();
      Type Parameters:
      B - The type of the field that the lens will focus on, which must not be null.
      Parameters:
      nullObject - The object to use when the focused field or its parent object is null. This object must not be null.
      lens - The Lens implementation to focus on the specified field of the parent object, using the null object when the parent object is null.
      Returns:
      A new Var that acts as a lens focusing on the specified field of the parent object, using the null object when the parent object is null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the supplied nullObject or lens is null.

    • zoomToNullable

      default <B extends @Nullable Object> Var<B> zoomToNullable(Class<B> type, Function<T,B> getter, BiFunction<T,B,T> wither)
      Creates a nullable lens property (Var) that focuses on a specific nullable field of the current property item. The lens is used by the returned property to zoom into an immutable nested data structure, allowing read and write operations on a specific nullable field via getter and wither functions.

      For example, consider a record User with a nullable email field. Using zoomToNullable, you can create a lens specifically for the email field, which is a nullable String. 

      
 var user = new User("sam42", MembershipLevel.GOLD, LocalDate.of(2020, 1, 1), "sam.sus@example.com");
 var userProperty = Var.of(user);

 // Creating a lens for the nullable email field
 var emailLens = userProperty.zoomToNullable(String.class, User::email, User::withEmail);

 // Usage example: Update the email via the lens
 emailLens.set(null);
      Type Parameters:
      B - The type of the nullable field that the lens will focus on.
      Parameters:
      type - The class type of the nullable field.
      getter - Function to get the current value of the focused nullable field from the parent object.
      wither - BiFunction to set or update the value of the focused nullable field and return a new instance of the parent object with the updated field.
      Returns:
      A new Var that acts as a lens focusing on the specified nullable field of the parent object.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the type, getter, or wither function is null.

    • zoomToNullable

      default <B extends @Nullable Object> Var<B> zoomToNullable(Class<B> type, Lens<T,B> lens)
      Creates a nullable lens property (Var) that focuses on a specific nullable field of the current property item, using a supplied Lens implementation. The lens is used by the returned property to zoom into an immutable nested data structure, allowing read and write operations on a specific nullable field via getter and wither functions.

      For example, consider a record record Employee(String name, @Nullable Department department). Using zoomToNullable, you can supply a Lens implementation to create a lens for the department field, which is nullable. The lens will allow you to read and update the department field of the employee record, even if it is null. 

      
   record Employee(String name, @Nullable Department department) {...}
   record Department(String name) {...}

   var lensToDepartment = Lens.of(Employee::department, Employee::withDepartment);
   // Create an Employee property
   var employee = new Employee("Alice", null);
   var employeeProperty = Var.of(employee);
   // Create a nullable lens property for the department field
   var departmentProperty = employeeProperty.zoomToNullable(Department.class, lensToDepartment);
      Note that the Lens is a generic interface. So instead of the Lens.of(Function, BiFunction) factory method, you may also create more elaborate lenses through a custom implementation.
      The lens in the above example may also be created like so: 
      
   var lensToDepartment = new Lens<Employee, Department>() {
     public Department getter( Employee employee ) {
         return employee.department();
     }
     public Employee wither( Employee employee, Department department ) {
         return employee.withDepartment(department);
     }
   };
      Type Parameters:
      B - The type of the nullable field that the lens will focus on.
      Parameters:
      type - The class type of the nullable field.
      lens - The Lens implementation to focus on the specified nullable field of the parent object.
      Returns:
      A new Var that acts as a lens focusing on the specified nullable field of the parent object.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the type or lens is null.
